reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Disturbing and riveting
reviews.reviewText: I just finished All The Broken Places by John Boyne. If a book can be disturbing and riveting all at the same time, it would describe this piece of historical fiction perfectly. This novel is the continuation of the story, The Boy in The Striped Pajamas. However, it primarily centers on Bruno's sister Gretel, and gives details of what happened to her and her family after the war. Like other historical fiction novels, this too alternated between past and present, a clever way to entice the reader to keep turning pages.I don't want to give too much away in regards to the plot, but what I will say is I had great difficulty liking the main character Gretel, a sign she was well written. At times I had to walk away from the novel because Gretel made me angry and my head spun. She was often self-absorbed and in great denial of the horrors the Nazi Party had created, and then just as quickly would be overcome with guilt and fear of others finding out about her, or her family's past. As the years go by, Gretel matures and appears to accept her family's guilt, while attempting to put the past behind her. But all dark secrets have a way of catching up as she will find in the most unpleasant way.All The Broken Places is very well written, as all John Boyne books tend to be. There are twists and turns in the story that I never anticipated and the ending was a bit of a shock, although I should have seen it coming. This novel was a great way to both continue and end the story of The Boy in The Striped Pajamas.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars compelling read. could not put the book down
reviews.reviewText: My heart broke for the burden Gretel carried her whole life, innocent but guilty at the same time. Boyce’s writing conjured up all of the emotions and memories Gretel experienced, conveying the same to the reader. It felt as though I was an observer in real time.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars one of his better stories
reviews.reviewText: The Hearts Invisible Furies is still the best. That is unbeatable. I trust this writer and want to read whatever he writes

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars great read. explores several difficult subjects
reviews.reviewText: I haven’t read Boy… but i saw the movieNot necessary to enjoy this novel3rd book i read by BoyneAll fantastic

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Couldn’t put it down!
reviews.reviewText: This is incredibly well written! The way the past and present are intertwined is breathtaking. Every night, I looked for a place where I could stop reading and get to sleep, but the intrigue just kept on growing and growing.I very highly recommend this book to everyone. I thought I liked only thrillers and murder mysteries, but now I have a new, loved, genre.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Deeply complex book
reviews.reviewText: This is a complicated story, filled with flawed and troubled people. It describes a catastrophic time in our world's history. When all we do is turn a blind eye in the presence of evil, are we guilty or innocent?

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2023
reviews.reviewText: The author brings you into the mind of a young girl whose father ran a Nazi death camp and describes how she copes with the guilt and shame this causes her as she grows up. The novel kept me involved in her fate.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Quite an intriguing thought provoking novel. I could not put it down. The plot was refreshing in that you got to see a tortured soul from a victim of circumstance
Es una novela muy bien manejada y que te invita a leerla sin soltarla. Gran manejo de los sentimientos y la mente.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 7, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Very interesting and thought provoking story of a German woman, daughter of a Nazi, in the aftermath of the 2nd World War

Brilliantly written book about a subject that is not explored much, the war from the perspective of those who were children then. The writing style is very engrossing and it’s a difficult book to put down.
A gripping story right from the start, you just won’t be able to put it down. Read “The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas” first.

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️📖19/2023📖All The Broken PlacesJohn Boyne⭐️ In this sequel to "The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas" Gretel, Bruno's sister, now aged 90, tells about her life after the war. Her father was hanged when she was 12, she and her mother escaped to France with a new identity. After a few years there, Gretel went to Australia, but she soon decided to come back to Europe and lived in England where she got maried and had a child.⭐️ Excellent book. Extremely well written, with this amazing capacity of the author to make everything clear. Should a 12 year-old be hold responsible for the actions of her father? How do you live with the fact that your father killed tens of thousand of people? Guilt, redemption, resilience, fear, love.⭐️@miss_books_isa
